newsitem.title: USA: Icahn buys into casino industry via Stratosphere.
newsitem.headline: Icahn buys into casino industry via Stratosphere.

text.p: Financier Carl Icahn, whose corporate takeovers range from airlines to comic books, is looking to buy his way into the high-stakes casino industry by acquiring the debt of bankrupt Stratosphere Corp.

A filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission late last week showed that two Icahn affiliates have acquired $81.8 million of Stratosphere's first mortgage notes, or about 40 percent of the $203 million currently outstanding.
In the filing, American Real Estate also outlined a proposed restructuring for Stratosphere under which the affiliates pledged to buy newly issued Stratosphere debt and equity.

Stratosphere opened a huge, $550 million resort in April 1996 with a great deal of fanfare and media hype. The property's centrepiece was a 1,149-foot tower -- touted as the largest structure west of the Mississippi River -- with a restaurant and rollercoaster planted firmly on top.

But management and facility problems, as well as a location on the Las Vegas "Strip" far from the main action, kept guests and gamblers away. By January, Stratosphere plummeted into Chapter 11 bankruptcy.
Since then, holders of the company's first mortgage notes and its controlling shareholder, Minnesota-based Grand Casinos Inc., have been negotiating over a company reorganization.
In late June, Stratosphere issued a revised restructuring plan that would give Grand Casinos 90 percent of the reorganized company and note holders 10 percent.
Stratosphere shares, which traded as high as $12.625 before the property's grand opening, are no longer listed on the Nasdaq stock exchange.
Last Friday, American Real Estate filed with the SEC to raise $300 million through an offering of rights to acquire depositary units in the company.

In its filing, American Real Estate said "the types of investments (it) will pursue include...acquiring debt or equity securities of companies which may be undergoing restructuring" among other targets.

It also outlined the investment in Stratosphere bonds and its proposed restructuring. Under their plan, the note holders could participate in a new, $200 million rights offering by Stratosphere to purchase new units consisting of new mortgage notes and common stock.
American Real Estate and the Icahn affiliate pledged to purchase their portion of the new issue and any units not purchased by the other noteholders.

Proceeds of the offer would be used to pay some of the company's creditors when the reorganization is completed. Also, note holders would be entitled to a pro rata portion of $100 million of the proceeds.
Executives at American Real Estate and Grand Casinos did not return calls seeking comment.

Icahn is perhaps best known for his purchase of Trans World Airlines Inc. in the mid-1980s. After losing control of the company in 1992, Icahn said he lost money in the deal and called it "the worst investment I've made in the last decade.

More recently, in June this year, Icahn used his position as a bondholder to gain control of bankrupt Marvel Entertainment Group Inc., a publisher of comic books with heroes like Spiderman and The Incredible Hulk.
